passages.text: The supreme art of war is to subdue the enemy without fighting.
passages.source: The Art of War

passages.text: If you know the enemy and know yourself, you need not fear the result of a hundred battles.
passages.source: The Art of War
passages.context: Dual knowledge as foundation of confidence

passages.text: Appear weak when you are strong, and strong when you are weak.
passages.source: The Art of War

passages.text: In the midst of chaos, there is also opportunity.
passages.source: The Art of War

passages.text: Let your plans be dark and impenetrable as night, and when you move, fall like a thunderbolt.
passages.source: The Art of War
passages.context: Contrast between stillness and explosive action

passages.text: Water shapes its course according to the nature of the ground over which it flows. The soldier works out his victory in relation to the foe whom he is facing.
passages.source: The Art of War

passages.text: The greatest victory is that which requires no battle.
passages.source: The Art of War
passages.context: Economy of force as highest art

passages.text: Be extremely subtle, even to the point of formlessness. Be extremely mysterious, even to the point of soundlessness.
passages.source: The Art of War

passages.text: Victorious warriors win first and then go to war, while defeated warriors go to war first and then seek to win.
passages.source: The Art of War

passages.text: Move swift as the wind and closely-formed as the wood. Attack like the fire and be still as the mountain.
passages.source: The Art of War

passages.text: All warfare is based on deception.
passages.source: The Art of War

passages.text: He who knows when he can fight and when he cannot will be victorious.
passages.source: The Art of War

passages.text: Opportunities multiply as they are seized.
passages.source: The Art of War

passages.text: The wise warrior avoids the battle.
passages.source: The Art of War
passages.context: Wisdom is knowing what not to do

passages.text: Attack him where he is unprepared, appear where you are not expected.
passages.source: The Art of War

passages.text: There is no instance of a nation benefiting from prolonged warfare.
passages.source: The Art of War

passages.text: Build your opponent a golden bridge to retreat across.
passages.source: The Art of War

passages.text: When you surround an army, leave an outlet free. Do not press a desperate foe too hard.
passages.source: The Art of War

passages.text: Strategy without tactics is the slowest route to victory. Tactics without strategy is the noise before defeat.
passages.source: The Art of War
passages.context: Balance of long and short term

passages.text: Treat your men as you would your own beloved sons. And they will follow you into the deepest valley.
passages.source: The Art of War

passages.text: The Moral Law causes the people to be in complete accord with their ruler, so that they will follow him regardless of their lives, undismayed by any danger.
passages.source: The Art of War, Chapter I
passages.context: Alignment of purpose between leader and people

passages.text: The Commander stands for the virtues of wisdom, sincerity, benevolence, courage and strictness.
passages.source: The Art of War, Chapter I
passages.context: The five virtues of a commander

passages.text: According as circumstances are favorable, one should modify one's plans. While heeding the profit of my counsel, avail yourself also of any helpful circumstances over and beyond the ordinary rules.
passages.source: The Art of War, Chapter I

passages.text: Hence, when able to attack, we must seem unable; when using our forces, we must seem inactive; when we are near, we must make the enemy believe we are far away; when far away, we must make him believe we are near.
passages.source: The Art of War, Chapter I

passages.text: If your opponent is of choleric temper, seek to irritate him. Pretend to be weak, that he may grow arrogant.
passages.source: The Art of War, Chapter I

passages.text: Now the general who wins a battle makes many calculations in his temple ere the battle is fought. The general who loses a battle makes but few calculations beforehand.
passages.source: The Art of War, Chapter I

passages.text: When you engage in actual fighting, if victory is long in coming, the men's weapons will grow dull and their ardor will be damped. If the campaign is protracted, the resources of the State will not be equal to the strain.
passages.source: The Art of War, Chapter II

passages.text: Thus, though we have heard of stupid haste in war, cleverness has never been seen associated with long delays.
passages.source: The Art of War, Chapter II

passages.text: It is only one who is thoroughly acquainted with the evils of war that can thoroughly understand the profitable way of carrying it on.
passages.source: The Art of War, Chapter II
passages.context: Understanding war's costs enables wise conduct

passages.text: In war, then, let your great object be victory, not lengthy campaigns.
passages.source: The Art of War, Chapter II

passages.text: Thus the leader of armies is the arbiter of the people's fate, the man on whom it depends whether the nation shall be in peace or in peril.
passages.source: The Art of War, Chapter II

passages.text: In the practical art of war, the best thing of all is to take the enemy's country whole and intact; to shatter and destroy it is not so good.
passages.source: The Art of War, Chapter III

passages.text: Hence to fight and conquer in all your battles is not supreme excellence; supreme excellence consists in breaking the enemy's resistance without fighting.
passages.source: The Art of War, Chapter III
passages.context: Winning without fighting as highest art

passages.text: Thus the highest form of generalship is to baulk the enemy's plans; the next best is to prevent the junction of the enemy's forces; the next in order is to attack the enemy's army in the field; and the worst policy of all is to besiege walled cities.
passages.source: The Art of War, Chapter III

passages.text: If you know the enemy and know yourself, your victory will not stand in doubt; if you know Heaven and know Earth, you may make your victory complete.
passages.source: The Art of War, Chapter III
passages.context: Extended version of the knowing principle

passages.text: The good fighters of old first put themselves beyond the possibility of defeat, and then waited for an opportunity of defeating the enemy.
passages.source: The Art of War, Chapter IV

passages.text: To secure ourselves against defeat lies in our own hands, but the opportunity of defeating the enemy is provided by the enemy himself.
passages.source: The Art of War, Chapter IV
passages.context: Control what you can, exploit what you cannot

passages.text: What the ancients called a clever fighter is one who not only wins, but excels in winning with ease.
passages.source: The Art of War, Chapter IV

passages.text: Hence his victories bring him neither reputation for wisdom nor credit for courage. He wins his battles by making no mistakes. Making no mistakes is what establishes the certainty of victory.
passages.source: The Art of War, Chapter IV
passages.context: Excellence is invisible - no errors means victory

passages.text: Whoever is first in the field and awaits the coming of the enemy will be fresh for the fight; whoever is second in the field and has to hasten to battle will arrive exhausted.
passages.source: The Art of War, Chapter VI

passages.text: Therefore the clever combatant imposes his will on the enemy, but does not allow the enemy's will to be imposed on him.
passages.source: The Art of War, Chapter VI

passages.text: You can be sure of succeeding in your attacks if you only attack places which are undefended. You can ensure the safety of your defense if you only hold positions that cannot be attacked.
passages.source: The Art of War, Chapter VI

passages.text: O divine art of subtlety and secrecy! Through you we learn to be invisible, through you inaudible; and hence we can hold the enemy's fate in our hands.
passages.source: The Art of War, Chapter VI

passages.text: Military tactics are like unto water; for water in its natural course runs away from high places and hastens downwards. So in war, the way is to avoid what is strong and to strike at what is weak.
passages.source: The Art of War, Chapter VI

passages.text: Do not repeat the tactics which have gained you one victory, but let your methods be regulated by the infinite variety of circumstances.
passages.source: The Art of War, Chapter VI

passages.text: We cannot enter into alliances until we are acquainted with the designs of our neighbors.
passages.source: The Art of War, Chapter VII

passages.text: Ponder and deliberate before you make a move. He will conquer who has learnt the artifice of deviation.
passages.source: The Art of War, Chapter VII

passages.text: If the enemy leaves a door open, you must rush in.
passages.source: The Art of War, Chapter XI

passages.text: Throw your soldiers into positions whence there is no escape, and they will prefer death to flight. If they will face death, there is nothing they may not achieve.
passages.source: The Art of War, Chapter XI

passages.text: The quality of decision is like the well-timed swoop of a falcon which enables it to strike and destroy its victim.
passages.source: The Art of War, Chapter V
